content.body:
ljharb: Regarding https://github.com/tc39/proposal-pipeline-operator/issues/262#issuecomment-1036323490, `source |> a + (# |> b + #)` is valid. It is the same as `source |> a + (b + #)` and `a + (b + source)`.

However, `source |> (a + # |> b) + #` is invalid, because `|> b` does not contain any topic reference.
content.formatted_body:
ljharb: Regarding https://github.com/tc39/proposal-pipeline-operator/issues/262#issuecomment-1036323490, source |> a + (# |> b + #) is valid. It is the same as source |> a + (b + #) and a + (b + source).

However, source |> (a + # |> b) + # is invalid, because |> b does not contain any topic reference.

ljharb: Regarding https://github.com/tc39/proposal-pipeline-operator/issues/262#issuecomment-1036323490, `source |> a + (# |> b + #)` is valid. It is the same as `source |> a + (b + #)` and `a + (b + source)`.

However, `source |> (a + # |> b) + #` is invalid, because `|> b` does not contain any topic reference.

ljharb: Regarding https://github.com/tc39/proposal-pipeline-operator/issues/262#issuecomment-1036323490, source |> a + (# |> b + #) is valid. It is the same as source |> a + (b + #) and a + (b + source).

However, source |> (a + # |> b) + # is invalid, because |> b does not contain any topic reference.

content.body: Also, `source |> a => # + a |> output(#)` is invalid because arrow functions (and all other non-pipe AssignmentExpressions) must be parenthesized in pipe bodies to prevent confusing grouping.
content.formatted_body: Also, source |> a => # + a |> output(#) is invalid because arrow functions (and all other non-pipe AssignmentExpressions) must be parenthesized in pipe bodies to prevent confusing grouping.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body: Also, `source |> a => # + a |> output(#)` is invalid because arrow functions (and all other non-pipe AssignmentExpressions) must be parenthesized in pipe bodies to prevent confusing grouping.
Also, source |> a => # + a |> output(#) is invalid because arrow functions (and all other non-pipe AssignmentExpressions) must be parenthesized in pipe bodies to prevent confusing grouping.

content.body: Thanks, the rules are straightforward but that doesnâ€™t mean contrived examples are intuitive :-)

We have banned `a |> # ? c : d` and require parentheses: `(a |> #) ? c : d` or `a |> (# ? c : d)`.

I think we should also ban `a ? b : c |> #` and require parentheses: `(a ? b : c) |> #` or `a ? b : (c |> #)`. This would add an early error to ConditionalExpression. I plan to add this to the spec later if nobody else has objections.
content.formatted_body:
We have banned a |> # ? c : d and require parentheses: (a |> #) ? c : d or a |> (# ? c : d).

I think we should also ban a ? b : c |> # and require parentheses: (a ? b : c) |> # or a ? b : (c |> #). This would add an early error to ConditionalExpression. I plan to add this to the spec later if nobody else has objections.

org.matrix.msc1767.message.body:
We have banned `a |> # ? c : d` and require parentheses: `(a |> #) ? c : d` or `a |> (# ? c : d)`.

I think we should also ban `a ? b : c |> #` and require parentheses: `(a ? b : c) |> #` or `a ? b : (c |> #)`. This would add an early error to ConditionalExpression. I plan to add this to the spec later if nobody else has objections.

We have banned a |> # ? c : d and require parentheses: (a |> #) ? c : d or a |> (# ? c : d).

I think we should also ban a ? b : c |> # and require parentheses: (a ? b : c) |> # or a ? b : (c |> #). This would add an early error to ConditionalExpression. I plan to add this to the spec later if nobody else has objections.
